content: Fixed bad input/output description (didn't match actual i/o)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice for Clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a nice, simple problem for Clash of Code.

A few things in the problem statement might need fixing.  First, the usual phrase (in en:us usage anyway) is "greater than or equal to" rather than "superior or equal to".  

Also, you have a variable "nb_day" in the constraints that isn't used anywhere in the problem statement.

You allow for p==0 in the constraints, but there is no test for that edge case.  I'd choose n=0 people needed to have probability p>=0.

You also allow for p==1 in the constraints.  That case has no solution, mathematically, but there's no output condition for "no solution".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea :smile:

It's good so long as your probabilities in the test and validator cases remain far enough away from exact values for f(n) to avoid the "floating point equality" problem.  (Not a problem with short decimal fractions, but watch out if you decide to add a "boundary value" edge case later...)

FWIW: Python 3.9 added math.perm(n,k) to compute the number of permutations of n elements taken k at a time.  That's n(n-1)(n-2)...(n-k+1) so you get a very high precision answer with 1 - math.perm(365,n)/365**n as the probability of at least one duplicate
You can have here informations about the birthday problem : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birthday_problem

Yes I agree. I tried to have very explicit results and keep test and validators far from boundary values.

So I would be surprised if the digit precision is a problem in this CoC.

I tried using math.perm(), it's a very good idea, I didn't know this function ! And it's much shorter. Thank you for your comment.

Hello Husoski,

Thank you for your advices !

I changed "superior or equal to" with "superior or equal to".

I choose to add an input nbdays which is always 365. But maybe it was just better to just remove it from constraints. Do you have an advice ?

For p==0 case, i agree the best choice is n=0, but it could also be n=-inf or n=1 if we want a minimum number of people. So maybe it's better to change constraints with "0 < p < 1" instead of "0 ≤ p ≤ 1".

And for p==1, I'm afraid of the floating position, because when I compile with p==1, I find result n=153. As you suggest it before, it's important to remain far enough from exact values to avoid the floating point equality. So again, maybe it's better to change constraints with "0 < p < 1" instead of "0 ≤ p ≤ 1".

Do you tink it's god with constraints "0 < p < 1" ?

Thank you for your comment
I like 0 < p < 1 as the best choice.
